values: Okay, so I'm on Google+ now. Just search my name and put me in one of your circles! I think it's going to eventually turn Facebook into Myspace, but maybe not. It'd take a few years anyway. But it's kinda like LJ in social-networking form! So if you're there, circle me or something! (Seriously, I'm barely on LJ anymore...so...I'm probably talking to myself.) Oh yeah, Magic City comics! I've updated the rest of "Dirty" so you have a complete story to read: Page 11, Page 12, Page 13, and Page 14. This story went through several artists before Anna Clinch, uh, clinched it. She's an awesome young lady, and maybe we'll work on something again someday. (That's not a cryptic hint or anything. I'm just speculating here.) Anyway, I'm going out of town for a week or so, and I won't be updating for another couple weeks. So come back in August for new comics!

Yeah, alright, I'm late with the update. Sheesh, I can't even keep a three week update going here. I'm sorry. LiveJournal is such an afterthought now. Remember when it used to be fun and new and stuff? Page 8, Page 9, and Page 10 of "Dirty" is now posted for your viewing pleasure. Your viewing of these pages better be pleasurable, goshdarnit!

So this may be my new normal. I'll just update this LJ with batches of new pages instead of just one page. It'll be easier because I'm lazy with actual blogging. Page 5, Page 6, and Page 7 are up and ready for you to read! Also, I did an interview with Grindstone Magazine, Billings's local alternative magazine, about me and Magic City. Unfortunately, they don't have a website and post their things online, but yay, someone else interviewed me! If you're in Billings and see a copy of the June issue, I'm in there along with my Zimmerman Trail comic!

Oh sweet science, I have been awful at updating this. There are more Magic City pages for your eyeballs, I swear! I have been updating every week, but well, Twitter and Facebook are so much quicker to update than LiveJournal, and yeah yeah, quit moaning about that, you big whiner. Page 2, Page 3, and Page 4 are up continuing the new story "Dirty" with art by the awesome Anna Clinch! If I forget to update LJ next week, I apologize, but I am still alive and updating and other things. Talk to you soon!

Look at this, a new Livejournal entry! Geez, I'm never on this anymore. I don't really blog anymore. But hey, if you want to read more weird things written by me, then follow me on the Twitter. I'm cleverly named @gregthelen there, and I say things! Sometimes they might amuse you. Oh, and I've started updating Magic City again! Geez, another long, long drought. I'm sorry about that. It's just really difficult sometimes to get things lined up with artists. They have their own schedules and lives, and things just happen. So, we got new comics for a while, and hopefully, we can update every week until the final comic (yes, it's happening) is completed. Hopefully. No promises. But hey, if you've stuck with me this long, then you're awesome and, sadly, used to these waits. First new page is the story "Dirty" featuring art by Anna Clinch, an artist I met on Twitter who I said "HI WANNA DO COMICS?!?!??!" and she eventually said yes. NOTE: This method will not work for everyone. Anyway, this story went through a few different artists before Anna worked on it, and she did a great job. And this is my first lettering job I've done, too, so yay for me! Hope you enjoy this weird, weird love story. Link to the site

I'm sure I'm forgetting a bunch of people and/or things that influence me, but I got into big blocks and was having fun doing so. There's a URL in the bottom that you can go to for the template. Good stuff.

So I started a new blog:  http://exit421.blogspot.com/

Why did I start a new blog, and why did I name it the same as this?  Well, I'm terribly unoriginal with names, apparently, and I wanted a fresh start.  Without repeating too much of what I said in my new blog, basically it's a fresh start for longer, more insightful rantings.  Mostly I'm going to talk about comics, making comics, writing comics, comics I like and whatnot, along with other posts about other things.  (Hint:  Underworld post on Friday.)

There's nothing really wrong with this blog, but LiveJournal is kinda dead, and mine is bogged down with personal stuff and Magic City updates.  I'll still post here from time to time.  I may even cross over entries.  But the Blogspot blog will, hopefully, contain better writing than what I do here.  (I am writing my posts ahead of time for this.)  We'll see.

Feel free to stop by and check it out.  I plan on updating on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays with something (to try and keep me writing on a schedule).  See ya there!

The final page of Kangna is now posted. Silent comics are always tricky to do, so hopefully this worked for you. Anyway, there's going to be another break between comics sadly. I thought I'd have something ready by now, but well, that didn't happen. So I'll try to keep you updated in the meantime.

Hey, so you probably know about that Park51/Cordoba Initiative/"Ground Zero mosque" that's not at Ground Zero nor a mosque but more like a Ramadan-flavored YMCA. If not, go on the internet or turn on a TV because it's everywhere. The whole debate is heated, stupid, frustrating, stupid, hate-fille, and did I mention stupid? Well, it is. I mean, it's like internet comment threads just spilled on over to real life. And one of the main "arguments" or picket sign slogans for it is this gem: I've seen this in many different places, and it's stupid. Yes, nothing like basing your worldview of 1.6 billion people on 19 morons. Yesterday, at work, I got some ideas on how to poke fun at this, and for your enjoyment, here they are. Feel free to share them, make up your own, whatevs. I have plenty of more ideas, but some aren't that funny or a little too harsh.

Page 7 of Kangna is posted, and we're getting close to the end of this story, and the beginning of another break. *sigh* When you don't pay artists, getting them to do anything is like trying to herd cats. With amnesia. This is one of the primary reasons I'm going to end Magic City. I've been lucky to work with the artists I have, but most of them are distracted by more pressing things than my silly scripts, so I do understand that. But, without naming names, some are only doing this as a hobby. I've been thinking of writing something about my experiences someday. That may be sooner rather than later.

Page 6 of Kangna is now posted. Go read it, and then go see Scott Pilgrim vs. The World. Like now...or the next available time. Seriously, it's a great movie, tons of fun, and not your typical Hollywood crap. The only way Hollywood stops making crap is by good movies making money. I've seen it three times already, may see it again. Please please go see it (three times)!

Page 5 of Kangna is now posted. Yeah, no picture tonight. Honestly, posting this on LiveJournal seems a little redundant to me since most of you are following me on Twitter or Facebook. Not to mention that LJ is practically dead, and it's been a month or so since anyone has commented on anything I've posted, and most of my posts are just Magic City updates. So...yeah. Anyway, I've outlined the end of Magic City yesterday. You'll see that maybe next year? Or 2012? Maybe I'll coincide it with the end of the world.

Hey folks, another Tuesday/Wednesday (depending on where you are in the world), and that means another page of comics! Page 4 of Kangna is up and waiting for your eyeballs. Btw, I had my eyes dialated today for an eye exam, and holy crap, were my eyes buggy afterwards. For like a half hour I couldn't see anything up close. Anyway, see you next week.

Page 3 of Kangna is posted early because I gots things to do! (Some menial, some...less menial.) Anyway, I didn't want to to forget to update this, so that's why you got it now. On a side note, I'm contemplating the end of Magic City. May not be until next year, but who knows. Thinking...
Alright, it's kinda late, so short update. Page 2 of "Kangna" is now posted. Remember, it's a silent story. See ya next week!

Hey, Magic City is back! Now for something different: Kangna, a silent comic featuring the return of Hushicho. Well, it's not completely silent; there's a short poem to start it off, and from then on, silent. These kind of comics are tough to pull off right, so hopefully we got things right. So see ya next week!

Alright, so I'm taking a week off from updating because I've had a hectic week (already), and I'm just going to take it easy tonight.  Plus, I need to do some prep for the next story, and that isn't done.

So Magic City will return next week.  I promise.

What the heck? The 15th and final page of "Zimmermon" is now posted? Yes, true believers! Um, excelsior! (Or whatever Stan Lee would say.) And I can't believe I'm done updating this story. I kinda wish it was longer, and there was a fourth part to follow Kurosawa's "Rashomon" structure more closely, but...well...I didn't think that far ahead. Anyway, go ahead and read it from the start to get the whole picture. Next week: something else!

Page 14 of Zimmermon is now posted, and we're almost there, people. We're almost THERE. I swear this thing will end. It won't consume you like it's consumed me for the page three months. The past three months! I started posting this story at the end of March, and now we're going into July. I didn't know it was going to be this way. I didn't KNOW. Back then, I was still fresh off the high from Emerald City ComiCon, and I thought, "Wow, COMICS. For MONTHS." I didn't know. I DIDN'T KNOW. Now, this story has consumed me. I am reporting from inside the belly of this comic, and slowly, so slowly, I am being digested. I can't tell, but I believe my feet are gone. From this COMIC. (I am fully imagining this as a John Campbell comic, which I haven't read for a while...because I'm being consumed!) ((Seriously, one more page to go.))
Hey, guess what what? Page 13 of "Zimmermon" is now posted! Betcha didn't see that coming, huh? Well, there it is! So go read it, already!
Page 12 of "Zimmermon" is now posted. This continues the awesomeness of Giorgio. We're almost done with this story, and man, I don't know what I'm going to do with myself when it's done.

Page 11 of "Zimmermon" is up, and now we're into the third and final part. This part features the return of Giorgio Iannotti, artist extraordinaire of Sacrifice Cliff (whose link I'm too lazy to look up now). Great artist. Love his work. I wish he had more time to make comics, but such is life, I guess.

Page 10 of "Zimmermon" is now posted, and we still have more to come for this story. In other news I had a root canal done today. Yay. I guess it's better than my tooth hurting forever and becoming infected and putrid and such. Feel a little better, but won't be able to chew for a while. Bring on the soup/oatmeal/yogurt/applesauce diet. Bleh.

Page 9 of "Zimmermon" is posted, and we're almost two-thirds of the way there! Yes, I said two-thirds! Want to know how many pages this is going to be? Use math! (Hey, just be glad I remembered to do this before going to bed.) See ya next week, dudes!
Page 8 of "Zimmermon" is now posted, and I swear, we're getting there, folks! Don't have much to say after that. I'm barely even awake (and spelling things correctly) at this hour in the morning.

Page 7 of "Zimmermon" is posted early. Gotta get up early and start a new temp job NOT at Wells Fargo. Whoopee. Still looking for permanent employment in Seattle, but no calls yet, unfortunately. Never really thought about how Magic City would be affected if and when I move out of Billings. I have an idea on how to end it, but it's big and huge and insane, so I have no idea how it'd get done. Hmmm. Ah well, enjoy the stories for the time being!

Page 6 of "Zimmermon" is posted, and what's this? We've switched artists in the middle of a story? Unheard of! (Apart from all the times the Big Two, Marvel/DC, do it, but still!) We're in the second chapter of "Zimmermon," and it features the return of Laszlo "Laci" Seber, the uhh... Flying Norwegian. Yeah, that's a terrible nickname. Anyway, he's back, and now where is this story going?

Hey hey, I gots a new computer! No longer the P.O.S. I had before. Now, I can actually run things. Yeah. Took me some time, and many calls to Indians and headaches later, to find a new router that works (hint: Netgear). Anyway, page 5 of "Zimmermon" is now posted! And a guy falls off the rims! Hmm, maybe that shouldn't be the selling point. It does happen, though. And things look to be wrapping up? Hmm, don't know about that.

Hey it's my birthday! (Shit, I'm almost 30!) Now go read my comics for me. Page 04 of "Zimmermon" is now posted. That's right, I'm too lazy and too old to read my own comics now. Do it for me, please!

Page 03 of "Zimmermon" is now posted, and more intriguing things happen! Sorry, I'm tired, and I'm terrible at hyping individual pages. But I promise, it gets more interesting in a couple weeks, and when it's completed, you'll get what's going on. See ya next week!

http://poisonrational.livejournal.com/236061.html Okay, so my good friend Rachel Dukes, who I met at ECCC and also did a rocking job on The Genie Bar for me, is having some tax troubles. She runs her own business, Poseur Ink, and well, the taxes...they trouble her. Some kind of taxes and things didn't go her way. So I suggest you all go and buy some of her merchandise. I picked up this at ECCC: It features art from a ton of great artists: Brandon Graham (King City and the guy who got me back to my cousin's after ECCC), Ryan Kelly (Local), Jim Mahfood (Clerks, Grrl Scouts) and so so many more! I know a lot of you music nerds are out there, and this is an anthology of great art all about how music affects us, influences us, and so on. I have a copy, and it's awesome. So you audiophiles out there, and I know there are a lot of you on LJ, get this now! There's also a Side A, which is the prequel (or something), and I'm planning on getting that. Why not buy one of each? I dare you to--no I double dog dare you music nerds! Haha, you know I kid! But seriously, help a girl out! Thank you.

Hey hai, page 2 of "Zimmermon" is now posted (a little early for MST, but it's Wednesday in most of the world, right?). The plot starts to thicken as this one guy starts to get all leery-eyed. See ya next week, folks!

Page 1 of "Zimmermon" is now posted, and we're back to stories that take longer than three pages to tell. "Zimmermon" is actually going to be the longest Magic City to run to date (which may or may not be exceeded by another story at some point in the future), and I'm okay with that. I like stories that take time to build. Of course, you won't see the end of this one by summer, so, yeah. Sit tight, folks. Oh, and not only does this story feature the return of Jose Sanchez to Magic City, it also features our tribute to Akira Kurosawa's amazing film, Rashomon. I remember seeing the movie back in an English class in high school as my teacher was trying to culture up us rowdy Montana kids. At first, I thought it was okay, but I was young and dumb back then (and so far, only one of those has really changed). Now, I see the brilliance of it, and I'm going to come out and say this in no way comes close to Rashomon. It'll be very good, maybe even great, but dudes, I can't touch Kurosawa. On my best day, I'd be his golf caddy. Or something... See? I'd bet Kurosawa could've come up with a better analogy and made a film about it that would stand the test of time as a classic.

Still coming down from the comic book high I had at ECCC, I came up with this comic using goodies I bought from Meredith Gran and Kate Beaton. (You can read up on my adventure and procurements a couple entries down.) FATPONY SHOTS!!! This is the Magic City update for this week, and I hope you enjoy it!

Hey, you like comics, don't you? Yes, yes you do. And you like comics about Russian sex goddesses, as well? Of course! Then, why not spare a few dollars that would've otherwise gone to fast food or coffee towards a comic about a Russian sex goddess? Surely! Go ahead and help out a friend of a friend and go without that Big Mac or frappuccino for a couple days. You'll feel awesome. And sexy. You'll feel sexy awesome, and really, what more could you want?

OCTOBRIANA site now online!

Posted using ShareThis

A day late, but the final page of The Genie Bar with art by Rachel Dukes! She did a fantastic job on this, and it was awesome hanging out with her this weekend. Would love to work with her again sometime. Not sure what's coming up next week. Decisions, decisions.

Where I meet my favorite creators, get drinks with new artist friends, Brandon Graham of King City gets me home, and I hand out comics to publishers Alright, so I am finally home from Emerald City ComiCon 2010! It was a blast, but it tired the hell out of me. I'll try to go in chronological order as much as I can remember what happened in what order. And so I don't completely invade your friends page, click on the link! Here's a pic of something I got to entice you to read through! Alright, so the first day was KARAZY! Way more people than I thought were there, mostly to see Leonard Nimoy and Stan Lee, but that was good to see a great attendance. Of course, it made walking around a chore. I brought a ton of stuff with me, so I chose day one to just browse and get as much stuff signed as possible. Also, whenever I saw someone dressed up, I stopped to take a photo. Some really great costumes were there! Brian Michael Bendis Michael Avon Oeming Kurt Busiek Mike and Laura Allred Danielle Corsetto Meredith Gran--forgot to get my picture with her Erika Moen After the con, I found Rachel Dukes and some of her friends and friends of friends that neither of us knew but eventually became our friends as well. Among those friends was Brandon Graham of King City fame. Well, I don't know if "fame" is the right word, but he was at the Image table, so that's a pretty good gig. I remember was trying to get his book a few years ago, and that it got some pretty good reviews (I think). Anyway, I knew about it, and it was great to meet and hang out with Brandon. He grew up in Seattle so he knew how to get to places. A cool, nice, mellow guy. I also met a couple of awesome artists: Natalie Nourigat and Emi Lenox. They were friends of friends that tagged along with Rachel, Brandon, and me as we went to grab a bite to eat at a baguette sandwich shop. I eventually discovered that they were both artists and had a table at the con, and you should most definitely check out their work! Natalie's, a.k.a. Tally, site is called Random Production, and you can get the links to all her stuff including her journal comic. Her art is fantastic, and um, she's beautiful, and I totally have a crush on her. And Emi is just one yarn ball of cuteness! Her site is called EmiTown. It will never fail to put a smile on your face. Rachel Brandon Natalie and Emi...if you can see them So after the baguette place, we went to a pub in an alley near Pike's Place (the alley has a name and has a lot of bars and restaurants and stuff, so it's well known in Seattle). We met some other comic book people who I never really got to know. But afterwards, Brandon helped me and Rachel get back to where we needed to be. We walked with Rachel to her hotel, and Brandon made sure I got to the right bus--even going so far as to ride with me for a while. This was above and beyond cool! And I promptly bought one of everything he was selling at the con the next day. When I saw him on Sunday, he asked me if I got home alright, and I thanked him a few more times for making sure I got on the right bus. So now I expect everyone to buy King City! Brandon Graham = awesome! Okay, onto the second day. It was much more chill on Sunday. Fewer people initially, and I got the chance to leisurely walk around without bumping into too many people. I even got the chance to meet Kate Beaton, get a sketch, and a fat pony figurine. If you ever see the number of comments on any one of her LJ posts, that was the number of people waiting in line on Saturday. She was a little late getting in on Sunday, so I was able to get near the front for her. And when she showed up, so did five billion people behind me (plus or minus a few billion). Then I went around handing out my Magic City presentations to publishers. First stop was the Oni Press booth, and being a little nervous and unsure of how to approach them, I browsed their books for a bit. Then a guy asked the man behind the tables if he could drop off a business card for them. He said sure, and I chimed in saying I had something to leave behind to. I handed him my presentation, and he was nice when he took it. Now, having some confidence, I went around to almost all of the publishers (discounting DC because they're for more established people), handing out six presentations in all. I have no idea if anyone will read my comics let alone email me, but who knows! Brandon Emi and Natalie Rachel Rachel and her friend, Sarah, at her Poseur Ink table And now to some things I bought. The first thing is the fat pony from Kate Beaton's Hark, A Vagrant!, followed by the shot glasses from Meredith Gran's Octopus Pie. And now to my sketchbook. Since I had a couple of stories about genies, I thought that'd be a good theme for my sketchbook. For some people, this caught them off guard as they don't usually think about genies, I presume. Jamie and Hazel of Girls With Slingshots by Danielle Corsetto Hannah and Eve of Octopus Pie by Meredith Gran by Erika Moen Kimiko from Dresden Codak by Aaron Diaz by Kate Beaton by Brandon by Pia Guerra of Y: The Last Man fame by Natalie, and my personal favorite by Emi, and the cutest of the bunch I didn't want to tear them out of the sketchbook and scan them in, at least not yet. I may frame a few of them, but anyway, I just took photos, so the quality isn't the best. Anyway, I had a great time at ECCC! I was exhausted (and still am), and I'm definitely going to make another go around next year (and it'll be three days instead of two). Met some great new people all around and got to hang out with Rachel, who turned out to be awesome! Who knows, maybe I'll have something to show people in a year (or two) and can get a table. My legs were killing me.

Almost forgot to update this, but page 2 of "The Genie Bar" is now up, in which Lucy Liu punches a frat boy! What more could you want? Also, I'm heading to Seattle tomorrow for Emerald City ComiCon! (Well, technically, it's this weekend, and I'm taking two days to drive to Seattle.) I'm taking presentations of three Magic City comics, "A Clear Voice," "Be Careful What You Wish For...," and "Sacrifice Cliff," that I printed off from Kinko's, and I'm going to try and hand them off to publishers in hopes they don't immediately throw them away. So we'll see how that goes. Oh, and I'll be meeting up with "The Genie Bar" artist, Rachel Dukes, the first artist I've worked with that I will have met in person! She's setting up a table for her Poseur Ink company, which publishes comics and makes t-shirts and buttons and things. Anyone reading this and attending (so far, just me that I know of) should definitely stop by her table and buy fifty of everything. And if you're not, then go to her site and buy fifty of everything. So I'm coming back next Wednesday, and the next update will likely be a day late. See ya next week!

Hey hey, Magic City is updated! Huzzah and hurrah! It's page one of "The Genie Bar" featuring the artwork of Rachel Dukes, , and it's the sequel to "Be Careful What You Wish For..." Not really based in Billings, but ah well. Also, as you'll notice from the redesign, the new pages aren't updated on the main page. Also, now I'm only updating on Wednesdays now. It's going to be the best way I can keep this updating with fewer gaps. But we'll see. Anyway, hope you guys and gals enjoy!

Whoa, so like you remember that webcomic thing I was doing a while back? Well, I'm still doing it! New comics are coming sooner rather than later, but it's gonna be a few weeks for that. In the meantime, I've completely redesigned the site, and I like it lots! Now you can comment on comic pages, though how I'm gonna keep up with any comments of old comics is beyond me at this point. Might just have to comb through them all every so often. Also, I've added some other goodies. Namely, desktop wallpapers! Here's some sample images for them. Go to the Media page to download them.

Early post! The final page of "Cobb Field" is now posted, and it will be the last update for a while. I have a couple more things in the works right now for Magic City, but it'll be a while before I can post.

Okay, I've done a horrible job keeping this blog updated with new Magic City updates. But I assure you that I've been updating for the past couple weeks. So just in case you've missed it, here are the links to pages 3-6 Page 3 Page 4 Page 5 Page 6, today's new page Also, I'll be posting the final page to "Cobb Field" on Monday next week just as I'm heading out of town for the rest of the week. Unfortunately, I don't have any new comics to post after that, so we'll be on hiatus again. But I will have some goodies for you all in the meantime.
Okay, I heard about DJ Hero coming out, but I never really paid attention to it. Now, I hear Daft Punk will be in the game, and I wanna play it.

Page 2 of "Cobb Field" is now posted, and we're in a flashback, people. Flashback warning! You will know the past before you know the present! Er, wait, that's nothing like a spoiler warning. Ah well.

Okay, so I'm not updating Magic City this week. I have a completed copy, but I want to give some space in between stories to allow other stories time to be completed. In the meantime, may I introduce you to Biff? Yes, I thought I might.

The final page of "Sacrifice Cliff" is posted, and after Hushicho's story, this is easily my favorite. When I saw Giorgio's art, I knew he was perfect for this tale, and he far exceeded my expectations. Now, for the non-Billingsian, you're probably wondering what this Sacrifice Cliff is. This is Sacrifice Cliff, and trust me, it's bigger than this photo indicates. It's just to the south of Billings, and it's easy to notice coming down from the Heights or westward on I-90. While the rims are just a random series of indistinct cliffs, Sacrifice Cliff is pretty distinctive. For years, I never knew the source of it's name. Turns out there are a couple variations on the story. One is the story you've just been reading. A group of Crow Indian warriors returned from battle to see their village ravaged by small pox. Seen as an act from the One Who Had Made Everything's disapproval, they sacrificed themselves to pay for whatever sins they committed. The other variation is of a young couple who were out on a joy ride instead of a group of warriors. While researching this story, I relied heavily on this wonderful poem by Bette Wolf Duncan. As for the ending, that was a little poetic license on my part. I'm not overly familiar with Crow folklore and beliefs, but I thought watching them all go splat would be in extremely poor taste. And in other news, I've been getting tons of hits from this one line review on stumbleupon.com! Seriously, the past three days alone, I've received more than 100 hits each day, almost completely due to stumbleupon.com. I have no idea how they found my webcomic, but I'm should send them a fruit basket or something.
Page 9 of "Sacrifice Cliff" is posted, and Giorgio floored me with this page. LOVE IT. Check it out!

Holy shit, Anthony Bourdain came to Montana for the Monday episode of No Reservations! He's sort of a rock star chef that travels the globe eating and writing (how can I get this job?) and occasionally takes in the local customs and activities of wherever he is. So what do you do when you come to Montana (apparently)? You fish, of course. Er, okay. Personally, I've never fished, but I'm an unusual Montanan. It looks like from the site they stayed in the Livingston/south central part of the state, which is too bad. I mean, what about the Flathead/Glacier area? Well, I guess I shouldn't speak too soon without watching the episode. Still, awesome.

Oh hell, I posted page 8 of "Sacrifice Cliff" on Thursday, and again, I forgot to even post here about this! Man, sorry about that. But we're getting close to the end, and the last two pages are golden. Trust me.
